body.text: There are several verbs that require a reflexive pronoun: the so-called reflexive verbs. Examples are zich herinneren (to recall), zich verslapen (to oversleep), zich vergissen (to be mistaken), and zich ergeren to be annoyed).

The reflexive pronoun is always placed immediately after the FF, whether or not the finite verb is the reflexive verb that the reflexive pronoun relates to. That is, the reflexive verb may be part of the OV (at the very right side), but its pronoun will be placed immediately after the FF (left side).

table: I cannot recall that incident very well
He has never washed himself with soap

body.text: Zich wijden aan (to dedicate oneself to):

table: aan het schrijven van een boek
We have dedicated ourselves to writing a book.

body.text: In all the above examples, the reflexive pronoun relates to a reflexive verb in the OV. There are no reflexive auxiliary verbs, which means that the reflexive verb is always the independent verb in a clause. If there are any OV, the reflexive verb is inevitably part of it.
If we phrase the last example as a clause without OV, we will find that the reflexive pronoun immediately follows after the reflexive verb:

table: aan het schrijven van een boek
We dedicated ourselves to writing a book.
